object.course_desc: Nature of language and linguistic knowledge. Formal description and analysis of language: phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture and tutorial three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Survey of topics in linguistics: language change, sociolinguistics, language acquisition and processing. May include language typology, language contact and writing systems.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): LING1001 (may be taken concurrently).
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001 (may be taken concurrently).

object.course_desc: This course explores some intriguing mysteries of language  - whether it is unique to humans, how children master its complexities so easily, how the brain handles language, how languages are born and die. These questions lead us to interesting discoveries about the human mind.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Phonological, morphological and syntactic analysis of linguistic data. Coursework consists primarily of practical exercises in data analysis.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING1001.
Lecture and tutorial three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001.

object.course_desc: Description of speech sounds; transcription systems; articulation; acoustics of speech sounds; perception of speech sounds; cross-linguistic diversity and phonetic universals; the role of phonetics in grammar.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING 2001 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING1001.
Lecture and tutorial three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001.

object.course_desc: Some of the central topics in the study of language and communication as pursued by linguists and philosophers. Topics include: the nature of meaning; the connections between language, communication and cognition; language as a social activity.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as PHIL2504, COMS2504.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A survey course highlighting a variety of communication differences and disabilities. Specific topics vary from year to year but typically will include speech, language, fluency and hearing differences and disabilities.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ALDS2604.
Prerequisite(s): second year standing or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A historical study of the English language, its structure, variety, and cultural contexts,with an introduction to grammatical terminology and constructions.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ENGL2105.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing or permission of the department.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Introduction to syntactic theory. Representation and analysis of sentence structure, syntactic relations and syntactic dependencies. Testing of grammatical hypotheses.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING2005.
Lecture and tutorial three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2005.

object.course_desc: Introduction to word structure and morphological theory. Topics include inflectional and derivational morphology, morphological processes, and interaction of morphology with phonology and syntax.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING2005 and LING2007.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2005 and LING2007.

object.course_desc: The sound-systems of languages, analysis of phonological structure; generative phonology; phonological rules and derivations; cross-linguistic diversity and universals; segmental phonology; stress; tone.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING 3002 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING 2001 (no longer offered) or LING2007.
Lecture and tutorial three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING 2001 (no longer offered) or LING2007.

object.course_desc: Selected topics in general linguistics not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. Contents of the course vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures and discussion three hours per week.

object.course_desc: The study of language in its conversational and cultural contexts. Topics include: conversational implicature; deixis; the semantics-pragmatics boundary; speaker's reference; speech acts. May include cross-cultural pragmatics.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as PHIL3504.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing, and one of LING1001, PHIL2001, PHIL2504/COMS2504/LING2504 or PHIL3506, or LING3505 or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing, and one of LING1001, PHIL2001, PHIL2504/COMS2504/LING2504 or PHIL3506, or LING3505 or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.

object.course_desc: Study of language meaning. Lexical meaning and meanings of larger linguistic expressions, including nominal units, verbal units, and sentences. Meaning relationships between utterances. Relationship between linguistic meaning (semantics) and contextual meaning (pragmatics). Basic formal treatments of semantics.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as PHIL3506.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing, and one of LING1001, PHIL2001, PHIL2504/LING2504/COMS2504 or PHIL3504/LING3504, or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing, and one of LING1001, PHIL2001, PHIL2504/LING2504/COMS2504 or PHIL3504/LING3504, or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.

object.course_desc: Introduction to adult language processing and neurolinguistics. Psychological processes underlying speech production and perception, word recognition and sentence processing. Biological foundation and neuro-cognitive mechanisms of language. Experimental techniques and methodologies of current psycholinguistic studies.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as PSYC3709.
Prerequisite(s): LING1001 or PSYC2700 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001 or PSYC2700 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Milestones associated with the development of grammatical, pragmatic and metalinguistic competence from birth to about age ten, and the relative contributions of the environment, cognitive development and inborn knowledge to this development.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as PSYC3508.
Prerequisite(s): LING1001 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: An in-depth examination of select topics in the field of communication differences and disabilities. An emphasis is placed on theoretical accounts of specific differences and disabilities and the cross-linguistic evidence for these accounts. Specific topics may vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ALDS3604.
Prerequisite(s): LING1001 and one of ALDS or LING2604.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001 and one of ALDS or LING2604.

object.course_desc: Computer-assisted analysis of electronic collections of naturally occurring language.  Applications in such areas as language variation, grammar, lexicology, phraseology, translation, and learner language.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as ALDS3701.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing in Applied Linguistics and Discourse Studies, or in Linguistics, or enrolment in the CTESL program, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing in Applied Linguistics and Discourse Studies, or in Linguistics, or enrolment in the CTESL program, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: The place of language within society; bilingual and multilingual communities; language, social mobility and social stratification; sociolinguistic factors in language change.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ALDS3202.
Precludes additional credit for ALDS 2701 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): ALDS1001 and third-year standing.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: ALDS1001 and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: Description and analysis of the structure of a specific language applying phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Language to be studied will be announced in advance by the School.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): LING 2001 (no longer offered) or LING2005 or LING2007.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING 2001 (no longer offered) or LING2005 or LING2007.

object.course_desc: Language change; sound change; analogy; the comparative method; internal reconstruction; the philological method; historical linguistics and pre-history; language change and theories of grammar.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for LING 3101 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING2007.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2007.

object.course_desc: Cross-linguistic survey of syntactic and morphological patterns found in the languages of the world. Typological classification and identification of language universals.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING 3001 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING2005.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2005.

object.course_desc: Research under the supervision of a member of the School. Normally available only to third- and fourth-year students in Linguistics.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Research under the supervision of a member of the School. Normally available only to third- and fourth-year students in Linguistics.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Advanced topics in syntax.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING 4002 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING3004 and third-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3004 and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: Advanced topics in morphology.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING3005 and third-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3005 and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: Advanced topics in phonology.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING 4001 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING3007, and third-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3007, and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: Examination of a topic or more specialized area in linguistics or language study. Topic to be announced. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third- or fourth-year standing in Linguistics or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5009, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third- or fourth-year standing in Linguistics or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Études des variétés du français, dans ses dimensions spatiales. Le contenu précis de ce cours varie selon les années. Consulter le site web du Département de français pour obtenir les détails. The course is taught in French, but students will submit written assignments in English.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as FREN4412.
Prerequisite(s): FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as FREN5412 and LING5412, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.

object.course_desc: Étude du français, dans ses dimensions historiques. Le contenu précis de ce cours varie selon les années. Consulter le site web du Département de français pour obtenir les détails. The course is taught in French, but students will submit written assignments in English.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as FREN4413.
Prerequisite(s): FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as FREN5413 and LING5413, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.

object.course_desc: Étude du français, dans ses dimensions morphologiques, syntaxiques ou phonologiques. Le contenu précis de ce cours varie selon les années. Consulter le site web du Département de français pour obtenir les détails. Course is taught in French, but students will submit written assignments in English.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as FREN4414.
Prerequisite(s): FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as FREN5414 and LING5414, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.

object.course_desc: Étude des variations internes de la langue, dans des dimensions orales/écrites. Le contenu précis de ce cours varie selon les années. Consulter le site web du Département de français pour obtenir les détails. Course is taught in French, but students submit assignments in English.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as FREN4415.
Prerequisite(s): FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as FREN5415 and LING5415, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: FREN2401 and FREN3050, or permission of the Department.

object.course_desc: Advanced topics in compositional semantics and its interfaces. Topics may include: logic, semantic types, lambda calculus, intentional contexts, possible world semantics, interfaces with syntax and pragmatics quantification, anaphora, presupposition, implicatures, scope and binding, and model theory.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as PHIL4505.
Prerequisite(s): LING3505 or PHIL3506, and third-year standing, or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3505 or PHIL3506, and third-year standing, or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Language Studies.

object.course_desc: Study of the meaning of words. Topics may include lexical decomposition, meaning variation, lexical relations, and lexical aspect.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as PHIL4055.
Precludes additional credit for LING 4055 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING3505 or PHIL3506, and third-year standing.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5510, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3505 or PHIL3506, and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: Further study of psychological and neurolinguistic mechanisms of adult language processing. May include topics from first language acquisition.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING3601 or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5601, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3601 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Advanced topics in language acquisition and development and the relative contributions of the environment, cognitive development, and inborn knowledge.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING1001 and LING3603.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5603, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING1001 and LING3603.

object.course_desc: Through seven-hour-a-week field placements, students pursue personal learning objectives concerning the clinical application of the psycholinguistics of communication disorders and cognitive development. A term paper integrates experiential knowledge gained in the placement with theoretical and empirical knowledge gained from the student’s program of study.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING3604, fourth-year Honours standing in B.A. or B.Sc. in Linguistics with a Concentration in Psycholinguistics and Communication Disorders with a CGPA of 10.0 in the major, and permission from the School of Linguistics and Language Studies.
Field placement one day a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING3604, fourth-year Honours standing in B.A. or B.Sc. in Linguistics with a Concentration in Psycholinguistics and Communication Disorders with a CGPA of 10.0 in the major, and permission from the School of Linguistics and Language Studies.

object.course_desc: Experimental methodologies used in current psycholinguistic studies. Topics include experimental design and techniques, descriptive statistics, and interpreting and reporting research findings.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING4009 Section "A" (2015-16 and 2016-17) and LING4009 Section "B" (2013-14) and LING4009 Section "C" (2017-18).
Prerequisite(s): third- or fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics or Cognitive Science, or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5605, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third- or fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics or Cognitive Science, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Application of statistical procedures to analysis of language data and to problems of measurement in experimental linguistics, applied linguistics, psycholinguistics, and related fields.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as ALDS4606.
Precludes additional credit for ALDS4906/LING4009 Section "B" if taken Winter 2015 or Winter 2016.
Prerequisite(s): Third-year standing in Linguistics or Applied Linguistics and Discourse Studies or Cognitive Science, or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5606 and ALDS5604, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Third-year standing in Linguistics or Applied Linguistics and Discourse Studies or Cognitive Science, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: With a language consultant, students discover the phonological, morphological, and syntactic structures of the target language using linguistic elicitation. Language will vary from year to year, but will normally be a non-European language.  Language documentation, data management, ethical issues surrounding research in Indigenous communities.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): LING2005 and LING2007.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as ALDS5801, for which additional credit is precluded.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2005 and LING2007.

object.course_desc: A theory-intensive course that will study the development of English starting with Proto-Indo-European progressing through Common Germanic to the stages of English itself. Topics include phonological sound changes, phonemic inventories, and morphological and syntactic typology.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for LING 4101 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): LING2005 and LING2007, and one of LING3005, LING3810 or LING3811.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as LING5802, ENGL5101., for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: LING2005 and LING2007, and one of LING3005, LING3810 or LING3811.

object.course_desc: Studies in Old English literature and its cultural and historical contexts. Instruction in grammar to facilitate reading knowledge of the Old English language.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ENGL4105.
Precludes additional credit for ENGL 3102 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
Seminar or lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Permits fourth-year Honours students to pursue their interests in a selected area of linguistics.
object.course_extra_details: Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Permits fourth-year Honours students to pursue their interests in a selected area of linguistics.
object.course_extra_details: Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Students choose existing study in linguistic literature, replicate the study, present findings, compare to original study. Practical experience gathering and preparing materials, running experiments, analyzing data, interpreting findings; real, important contributions to the field of linguistics via replication studies (as mandated by the scientific method).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING4910.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics, with a Major CGPA of 9.0, and permission of the instructor.
Unscheduled.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics, with a Major CGPA of 9.0, and permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A thesis project selected in consultation with the School and carried out under the direction of a faculty supervisor.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for LING4905.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics with a CGPA of 10.0 in the major; one of LING3004, LING3007, LING3505, or LING3601; and permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year Honours standing in Linguistics with a CGPA of 10.0 in the major; one of LING3004, LING3007, LING3505, or LING3601; and permission of the instructor.
